questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess.
  • It is suppuration of the parotid space. Deep cervical fascia splits into two layers, superficial and deep, to enclose the parotid gland and its associated structures. Parotid space lies deep to its superficial layer.
  • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
  • Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Presents with unilateral swelling associated with redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present.
  • Investigations -
    • Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan – to know extent of abscess
    • Aspiration of abscess for culture and sensitivity to isolate causative organism
  • Treatment -
    • Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision along with IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: is a complication of mastoiditis which presents as swelling in upper part of neck when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid

 

Option C. Upper cervical lymphadenopathy: occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

 

Option D. Osteoma of the mandible: characterized by a benign, slow-growing tumor on the mandible, which is usually painless and asymptomatic, not presenting with tenderness and acute symptoms like an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:


Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 297

questions.text: A primigravida presented to the labor room at 38 weeks. At 1 pm she is 5 cm dilated. After 4 hours she is 6 cm dilated. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ARM + oxytocin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is experiencing protracted labor, as indicated by a slow progression in cervical dilation (only 1 cm increase in 4 hours). In active labor, the cervix is expected to dilate at a rate of approximately 1 cm per hour. Here, the cervix dilated from 5 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours, indicating a slow or protracted dilation phase.

 

Management of Protracted Labor:

 

Assessment: Evaluate the cause of slow labor, which could be due to issues with powers (uterine contractions), the passage (pelvis), or the passenger (fetal position or presentation).

 

Augmentation of Labor:

 

  • 1st step: ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes): This can help enhance uterine contractions and allow assessment of the amniotic fluid for the presence of meconium, which could indicate fetal distress.
  • 2nd step: Oxytocin: If contractions remain inadequate after ARM, oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and accelerate labor progress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait for 4 hours and reexamine: This is not recommended as it allows prolonged labor to continue without intervention, increasing the risk of complications.

 

Option B. LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While a cesarean section may be necessary if augmentation fails or if there are other indications, it is not the immediate next step without attempting augmentation.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps can only be applied when the cervix is fully dilated (10 cm), not at 6 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a primigravida with protracted labor (slow cervical dilation), the next best step is to perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and administer oxytocin to augment labor and promote adequate uterine contractions.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

questions.text: First deformity corrected in CTEV is:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavus

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINO VARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Incidence: 1:1000 live births
  • M:F – 2.5:1
  • 50% are bilateral
  • In its most characteristic form, there are four elements of deformity – Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • Conservative Management:

 

 

  • First cast in CTEV is applied in supination to correct cavus.
  • Subsequently in kites, one deformity is corrected at a time, adduction first then varus and then equinus (CAVE).
  • In ponsetti method, adduction and Varus are corrected simultaneously and Equinus is corrected at last.
  • Thus in Kites method, one deformity is corrected at a time but in ponsetti adduction and varus are corrected simultaneously, equinus is corrected at end in both.

 

 

Sequential correction

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Forefoot adduction. This is corrected after the correction of the cavus deformity of the foot. (CAVE)

 

Option C. Varus. This is corrected after the correction of cavus followed by forefoot adduction. (CAVE)

 

Option D. Equinus. This is corrected in the last because it is the most resistant deformity. (CAVE)

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate
Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine
Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate
Start only anti-TNF alpha agents

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine

 

Adding sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine to the treatment regimen for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is not responding adequately to methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids is a sound strategy. This approach follows the principle of combining different disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to achieve better disease control. Both sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine are DMARDs that work by different mechanisms to reduce inflammation and slow disease progression in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate: While switching to parenteral administration can increase the effectiveness of methotrexate for some patients, it might not be sufficient alone if the disease is still progressing.

 

Option C. Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate: Continuing the same treatment without modification is not advisable if the disease is actively progressing, as this indicates that the current regimen is insufficient.

 

Option D. Start only anti-TNF alpha agents: While anti-TNF agents are effective for many patients, they are typically used after trying combination DMARD therapy, especially in cases not severe enough to warrant immediate biologic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis does not respond adequately to initial therapy with methotrexate and corticosteroids, the addition of other DMARDs such as sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine can be beneficial.

 

Drugs:

 

  • Methotrexate: Start 10mg/week → max 25mg/week along with Folic acid twice/week
  • Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation
  • Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs.
  • Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !!
  • Symptomatic relief with NSAID and short course corticosteroids.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatoid arthritis/ Chap 358

questions.text: A rose gardener with a history of thorn prick presents with the following lesions. What is the possible causative agent? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Diagnosis from the given findings is Sporotrichosis.

 

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear nodulo-ulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in:

 

  • Fish tank/Swimming pool granuloma
  • Lupus vulgaris.

 

The given image shows the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology: Asteroid bodies are seen as shown in the image below.

 

 

Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes:

 

  • While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections, it is not typically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening.
  • This bacterium is more commonly linked with pharyngitis, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis:

 

  • This is an intestinal nematode and is not associated with skin lesions from thorn pricks.
  • It primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms and can cause systemic disease in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus:

 

  • This bacterium can indeed cause skin infections, but the scenario described is not its classic presentation.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can take advantage of wounds to cause infection, but it is not specifically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of thorn prick, especially a gardener, presenting with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels, the most likely causative agent is Sporothrix schenckii, responsible for sporotrichosis, a fungal infection commonly associated with gardening activities.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition, Chapter 32 Page no 32.71

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 297

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition Page no 1542

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Malaria (A-4, Giemsa stain): Giemsa's solution is a mixture of methylene blue, eosin, and Azure B. It is used to stain blood smears for the identification of malarial parasites. Giemsa's stain is regarded as the world's standard diagnostic technique for malaria's plasmodium, and it is also the basic stain for classifying lymphomas in the Kiel classification.
  • Tuberculosis (B-1, ZN stain): The Ziehl-Neelsen method uses a carbol fuchsin stain, acid alcohol decolorizer, and methylene blue counterstain. Acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, stain red, while the background of debris stains blue. The ZN stain confirms the acid-fast property of mycobacteria.
  • Leprosy (C-2, Fite Faraco stain): Fite-Faraco stain is the routinely used method to demonstrate Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. It is more sensitive than the ZN method in the detection of Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. The leprosy bacillus is much less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus, therefore alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

Mycobacterial cell walls contain a waxy substance composed of mycolic acids. These are ß-hydroxy carboxylic acids with chain lengths of up to 90 carbon atoms. The property of acid fastness is related to the carbon chain length of the mycolic acid found in any particular species.

 

  • Actinomycosis (D-3, Gram stain): Actinomyces species are gram-positive bacteria, and the Gram stain is used to visualize them. Actinomyces appear as filamentous, branching, gram-positive rods when stained with the Gram stain. Gram stain is more sensitive for the diagnosis of actinomycosis than culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia

 

 

The patient's condition suggests a subcutaneous infection that has progressed to involve deeper tissues, leading to a discharging ulcer. The key diagnostic clue here is the microscopic finding of gram-positive filamentous rods with branching, which is characteristic of Nocardia. Nocardia is a type of actinomycete, a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their branching filamentous structure. This presentation is consistent with actinomycetoma, a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria, as opposed to eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Candida is a yeast, not a gram-positive filamentous rod. It typically presents as budding yeasts and pseudohyphae rather than branching rods, making it an incorrect option for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which presents with ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels. It does not appear as gram-positive filamentous rods, making it inconsistent with the given microscopic findings.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus that appears as intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. It does not have the filamentous, branching rod structure observed in this case, eliminating it as a possible answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • The clinical vignette is suggestive of male pseudohermaphroditism.
  • In pseudohermaphroditism, the sex glands are of one sex while the external genitalia are of the opposite sex.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (male intersex) is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia.
  • In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concealed sex: Criminals may conceal their sex to avoid detection by changing dress or by other methods. This is not relevant to the clinical scenario presented.

 

Option B. True hermaphroditism: In this condition, the glands of both sexes must be present in the same individual. Such cases are very rare. In most cases, the accessory sex gland is atrophic and lacks functional activity.

 

Option C. Female pseudohermaphrodite: The fault is at the level of an enzyme block of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (21 hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause) leading to defective production of sex steroids. There are features of virilization (clitoromegaly and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum). The ovaries may descend within the inguinal canal to lie in the labia majora simulating an inguinal testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology  6th edition pg 443

choices.text: Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS
Start Antihypertensives and ARM

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

 

Explanation:

 

Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.

 

Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.

 

Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaint of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and secondary sexual development. On examination, there was webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with the given condition? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45 XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in females. The key features that suggest Turner syndrome in this patient are:

 

  1. Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea: Due to the presence of streak gonads (non-functional ovaries) in Turner syndrome, patients often experience delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods).
  2. Lack of secondary sexual development: The absence of functional ovaries leads to a lack of estrogen production, resulting in poor development of secondary sexual characteristics, such as breast development and pubic hair growth.
  3. Webbed neck: A short, wide neck with excess skin folds (webbing) is a common physical feature in Turner syndrome.
  4. Widely spaced nipples (shield chest): This is another characteristic physical finding in Turner syndrome, resulting from the altered body proportions.

 

 

The karyotype associated with classic Turner syndrome is 45,X (also written as 45,XO), indicating the presence of only one X chromosome instead of the normal two in females. This monosomy of the X chromosome is responsible for the clinical features observed in Turner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 47, XXX (Triple X syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in females but does not typically present with the features described in the question.

 

Option B. 46, XX: This is the normal female karyotype and does not explain the clinical presentation of the patient.

 

Option D. 47, XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in males and presents with different clinical features, such as tall stature, gynecomastia, and hypogonadism.

 

Additional information:

 

Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of various complications, such as:

 

  1. Congenital heart defects (e.g., coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve)
  2. Metabolic syndrome (obesity, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia)
  3. Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, celiac disease)
  4. Osteoporosis due to estrogen deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the 45,XO karyotype, should be suspected in a female patient presenting with delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, lack of secondary sexual development, and characteristic physical features such as webbed neck and widely spaced nipples.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child brought to the OPD with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks, and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Measles/Rubeola

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: The rash of rubella is similar in distribution to that of measles (rubeola) but it is less intensely red and confluent. Forchheimer spots (Red spots over palate) may be present.

 

 

Option C. Varicella: Varicella presents with rash which appears 24-48 hrs after prodromal symptoms, then rapidly to face & trunk. There are papules, vesicles & crusted vesicles, Centripetal distribution with greatest on trunk.

 

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps presents with Painful enlargement of salivary gland, ear ache, jaw tenderness while chewing, dryness of mouth.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koplik spots and a characteristic rash that begins on the forehead behind the ears and spreads to the torso and extremities are pathognomonic for measles.

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except: (INICET NOV 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Iritis, or inflammation of the iris, is not commonly associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). Instead, RA is more commonly linked to other ocular conditions such as episcleritis and scleritis, which affect different parts of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus can involve various parts of the eye, including the development of uveitis, which includes iritis.

 

Option B. Ulcerative Colitis: This inflammatory bowel disease is known to have extraintestinal manifestations including uveitis, which encompasses iritis.

 

Option C. Behcet's Disease: This is a multisystem inflammatory disorder that commonly affects the eyes, including the iris, making iritis a typical manifestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis is typically associated with scleral and episcleral inflammation rather than iritis, distinguishing it from other autoimmune conditions like SLE, Ulcerative Colitis, and Behcet's Disease that can present with iritis as a part of their systemic manifestations.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: While assessing children's nutritional status in a school, you come across a child with low height for age. What is this known as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stunting

 

Explanation:

 

Low height for age is referred to as stunting. Stunting is an indicator of chronic malnutrition, where the child's growth has been inhibited over a prolonged period.

 

Note – Stunting is also known as Dwarfism

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Underweight: Low weight for age is known as underweight. It can indicate acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option B. Wasting: Low weight for height is referred to as wasting. This indicates acute malnutrition, where there has been a significant recent weight loss. Wasting is also known as Emaciation.

 

Option C. Overweight: This indicates excess weight relative to height.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low height for age is known as stunting and indicates chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

Valsalva maneuver can lead to a temporary increase in blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system. This phenomenon can be explained by:

 

  • Increased Intrathoracic Pressure: By trying to exhale against a closed airway, you create increased pressure within your chest cavity. This can compress the large blood vessels.
  • Increased Sympathetic Activity: The increased intrathoracic pressure triggers the body’s sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response. This leads to the release of stress hormones like adrenaline and norepinephrine. These hormones cause blood vessels to constrict (vasoconstriction), which further raises blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. The pressure increase primarily affects the aorta and systemic circulation, not just the left ventricular pressure.

 

Option C. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While there may be a slight increase in left atrial pressure, it is not the primary cause of the rise in blood pressure observed during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. The maneuver does not directly increase left ventricular volume; instead, it increases pressure within the thoracic cavity affecting the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

questions.text: A 32 weeks pregnant woman is at risk of GDM. She would have likely had a screening test during which time of pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24-28 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically diagnosed during pregnancy and is due to the hormonal changes associated with pregnancy. These hormonal changes, particularly the placental hormones, cause increased insulin resistance, which generally becomes apparent after 24 weeks of gestation.

 

The optimal time to screen for GDM is between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy.

 

This period is chosen because it is when the effects of placental hormones on glucose metabolism become significant enough to detect any abnormalities in glucose tolerance.

 

Screening Methods:

 

  1. IADPSG Criteria (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups):
    • A 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is performed.
    • Blood glucose levels are checked fasting, at 1 hour, and at 2 hours after glucose intake.
    • Diagnostic criteria:
      • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
      • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
      • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
    • Any one of these values being abnormal is diagnostic of GDM.
  2. DIPSI Criteria (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India):
    • The patient does not need to be fasting.
    • A 75-gram glucose load is given, and blood glucose is checked after 2 hours.
    • A value ≥ 140 mg/dL is diagnostic of GDM.

 

Note - First visit is the time to screen for pre-existing diabetes or overt diabetes in women who may not know they are diabetic. It is not the typical time for GDM screening, which occurs later in pregnancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

The appropriate time to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus is between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy, as this is when the impact of placental hormones on glucose metabolism is most apparent.

questions.text: Rice water diarrhoea, intoxication is due to which ganglioside?(NEET PG  2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM-1 ganglioside receptor.

 

Explanation:

 

Rice water diarrhea is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae is the cholera toxin.

 

The cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding leads to the activation of adenylate cyclase, increased levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), and subsequent secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic rice water diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM-2 ganglioside receptor: GM-2 ganglioside is not related to cholera toxin binding. Instead, it is involved in diseases like Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease, where there is a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase, leading to the accumulation of GM-2 ganglioside.

 

Option C. GM-3 ganglioside receptor: GM-3 ganglioside is not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin. It is a simpler ganglioside involved in different cellular processes but not specifically in the pathology of cholera.

 

Option D. GD-1a ganglioside receptor: GD-1a ganglioside is not associated with the cholera toxin. It has roles in neural cell function and development but does not play a part in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:


Cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells, causing the characteristic rice water diarrhea by increasing cyclic AMP levels and promoting water and electrolyte secretion into the intestinal lumen.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 202

questions.text: What is true regarding normal semen parameters? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Motility >32%

 

Explanation:

 

According to the recent guidelines on normal semen parameters, progressive motility should be more than 32%. This is an important indicator of sperm health and fertility potential. The motility of sperm refers to their ability to move efficiently, which is crucial for natural conception as the sperm must travel through the female reproductive tract to fertilize the egg.

 

Other Options:

 

The other parameters provided in the options are either outdated or incorrect according to the latest guidelines:

 

Option B. Sperm count > 20 million: The current guideline indicates that the sperm count should be more than 16 million per milliliter, not 20 million.

 

Option C. Morphology < 8%: The normal morphology (shape and structure) of sperm should be more than 4%, not less than 8%. This means that at least 4% of the sperm should have a normal shape.

 

Option D. Sperm concentration < 40 million/ml: The correct parameter is that sperm concentration should be more than 16 million per milliliter, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational objective:

 

The correct parameter for normal semen analysis regarding motility is that progressive motility should be more than 32%.

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

An oil drop cataract is a specific type of cataract that is characteristically seen in patients with galactosemia. Galactosemia is an inherited disorder of galactose metabolism, where the body is unable to properly process galactose, a sugar found in milk. As a result of the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens of the eye, a cataract forms that resembles an oil droplet when viewed under certain lighting conditions. This cataract is often congenital or develops early in life, making it a common cause of pediatric cataracts.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. While it affects various organs, it does not typically cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Option C. Tay-Sachs disease: Tay-Sachs disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. It primarily affects the central nervous system and does not cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil drop cataracts are a hallmark feature of galactosemia, an inherited disorder affecting galactose metabolism, and they can present as congenital or developmental cataracts in pediatric patients.

choices.text: A, B and C
B and C only
B and D

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Carbamazepine

B. Valproate

C. Ethosuximide

D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B and C only

 

The first line drugs for treatment of absence seizures are valproate and ethosuximide. Carbamazepine and phenytoin are contra-indicated in absence seizures.

 

Drugs Used in Absence Seizures

 

  • Ethosuximide: This drug is specific for absence seizures. It works by blocking T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are believed to play a role in the generation of absence seizures.
  • Valproic Acid (Valproate): Valproate is effective in treating a wide range of seizure types, including absence seizures. It works by increasing GABA levels and blocking sodium and calcium channels. Valproate is also used for bipolar disorder and migraine prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is not used for absence seizures. In fact, it can exacerbate absence seizures. It is typically used for partial seizures and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Options D. Gabapentin: Gabapentin is not effective for absence seizures. It is mainly used for neuropathic pain and as an adjunctive treatment for partial seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN ABSENCE SEIZURES

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMG CoA reductase

 

Explanation:

 

HMG CoA reductase (3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl-CoA reductase) is the rate-limiting enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. It catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a critical step in the production of cholesterol. This enzyme is a major target for statins, a class of drugs used to lower cholesterol levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 7-alpha hydroxylase: This enzyme is involved in bile acid synthesis from cholesterol, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I: This enzyme is involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option D. Carnitine acyltransferase II: This enzyme is also involved in fatty acid metabolism, specifically in the mitochondrial matrix, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, making it a critical target for cholesterol-lowering therapies.

 

Note – Rate limiting enzyme of ketone bodies synthesis - HMG CoA Synthase

choices.text: It is done as a life-saving measure
It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking
It is done for emotional care and support
It is done for good functionality

questions.text: A person fell from the train and injured his both legs a few years back. The amputation was done as shown in the image. What is the most likely reason for doing such an amputation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is done as a life-saving measure

 

In cases of severe traumatic injury, such as a person falling from a train and suffering significant leg injuries, amputation is often performed as a life-saving measure. When a limb is crushed, it can lead to a crush syndrome, where the release of myoglobin and potassium from the damaged muscles into the bloodstream can cause acute tubular necrosis of the kidneys and hyperkalemia, leading to fatal arrhythmias. To prevent these life-threatening complications, immediate amputation of the crushed limb is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking: While amputations are sometimes performed with prosthetic use in mind, this is not the primary consideration in emergency situations involving severe trauma.

 

Option C. It is done for emotional care and support: Amputation is not performed for emotional care; it is a surgical intervention aimed at addressing severe physical injuries.

 

Option D. It is done for good functionality: Functionality considerations, such as optimizing the stump for prosthetic fitting, are secondary to the immediate need to save the patient’s life in cases of severe trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of severe limb trauma, such as a crush injury, amputation is primarily performed as a life-saving measure to prevent complications like crush syndrome and its associated risks.

choices.text: A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4
A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

The chronology of eruption of secondary dentition or permanent teeth is as follows:

 

  • Canine: Erupts at 11-12 years (A-3)
  • Lateral incisor: Erupts at 8-9 years (B-2)
  • First molar: Erupts at 6-7 years (C-1)
  • Third molar: Erupts at 17-25 years (D-4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronology of eruption of secondary dentition or permanent teeth:
 

 

Mnemonic: Mother Is In Pain Papa Can Make Medicine

questions.text: What is the skin manifestation seen resulting from drugs used to treat amebic dysentery? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

 

  • Among the various medication available, metronidazole is drug used to treat amebic dysentery most frequently & it is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE), which is a drug-induced skin manifestation.
  • Metronidazole can cause maculopapular rashes, but it also has a higher likelihood of causing a fixed drug eruption.
  • Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They can cause a burning sensation and appear on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa.
  • They frequently appear alone or in small groups and return to the same spot. On re-exposure to the harmful drug, however, new lesions may develop on various body parts. FDE is a form of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Some of the most frequently prescribed medications that cause FDE are NSAIDs Tetracyclines and paracetamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urticaria

 

  • While urticaria (hives) can be a common reaction to many drugs, it is not specifically associated with the treatment of amoebic dysentery.
  • Urticaria is characterized by raised, often itchy, red or skin-colored wheals on the surface of the skin as shown below.

 

 

  • It is usually as an immediate hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Option C. Maculopapular rash

 

  • A maculopapular rash is a skin change that can occur with many conditions or as a reaction to various drugs.
  • It is characterized by a flat, red area on the skin that is covered with small confluent bumps as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • While this type of rash can be seen with many types of medications, it is not the most characteristic skin manifestation resulting from drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, inflamed skin.
  • It is not a drug-induced condition but rather a type of eczema that has a strong genetic predisposition and is commonly associated with allergic diseases.
  • It is not typically associated with amoebic dysentery treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole).
  • While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles.

 

 

  • Complicated or secondary cataracts develop due to inflammatory or degenerative conditions of the lens or other parts of the eye.
  • Causes of these cataracts include iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors which disturb the nutrition of the lens.
  • These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster.
  • Vision impairment occurs even in the early stages due to location of the cataract at the nodal point.
  • Inflammation of the posterior segment causes posterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: This is a feature seen in complicated cataracts where the lens exhibits a colorful sheen, often described as having a "christmas tree" or polychromatic appearance, particularly noticeable under slit-lamp examination.

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Uveitis, an inflammatory disease affecting the uveal tract of the eye, can lead to the development of complicated cataracts. Chronic inflammation can disrupt the lens, leading to cataract formation.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: This refers to the appearance of small opacities within the lens, resembling breadcrumbs, commonly seen in complicated cataracts due to intraocular inflammation or other degenerative changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Krukenberg spindle is a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea, commonly seen in pigmentary glaucoma. It results from the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris that adhere to the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: A 1-day old neonate presented with scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress and mediastinal shift. All of the following can be done except? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation

 

Bag and mask ventilation can be challenging and less effective in the presence of a scaphoid abdomen and mediastinal shift. In such cases, positive pressure ventilation through an endotracheal tube or a ventilator may be more appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. O2 by mask: This is a valid intervention. Providing oxygen by mask can be an initial step to improve oxygenation in a neonate with respiratory distress. The goal is to support oxygenation until more definitive measures can be taken.

 

Option B. Positive pressure ventilation by ventilator: This is a valid intervention. Positive pressure ventilation with a ventilator may be necessary in cases of severe respiratory distress or failure. It helps to provide adequate oxygenation and ventilation to the neonate.

 

Option C. ET intubation: This is a valid intervention. Endotracheal (ET) intubation may be indicated in cases where positive pressure ventilation is required or to secure the airway in the presence of respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical signs of diaphragmatic hernia, such as a scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, and mediastinal shift. Understand the appropriate interventions, including oxygen administration, positive pressure ventilation, endotracheal intubation, and the limitations of bag and mask ventilation in specific clinical scenarios.

questions.text: Most common complication of ERCP is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

Explanation

 

The most common complication of Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is pancreatitis. The incidence of post-ERCP pancreatitis is approximately 5-10%, although may vary slightly with ranges from 3.5% to 9.5%. Despite this relatively high incidence, the majority of these cases are mild and can be managed conservatively. Severe acute pancreatitis occurs in less than 1% of cases following ERCP.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cholangitis: Although a potential complication, it is less common than pancreatitis following ERCP.

 

Option B. Duodenal Perforation: This is a rare but serious complication.

 

Option C. Bleeding: Another potential complication, but less common compared to pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Pancreatitis is the most common complication following Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), occurring in approximately 5-10% of cases.

questions.text: Image a of child with an orofacial cleft as shown. When is the first repair done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

The initial repair for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age. According to Millard's Rule of 10, the surgery is ideally done when the infant is at least 10 weeks old, weighs around 10 pounds (approximately 4.5 kilograms), and has a hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter. This timing helps ensure the child is sufficiently mature and robust for surgery, minimizing surgical risks and optimizing healing.

 

Repair of the cleft lip/nose and anterior palate generally occurs between 3 to 6 months of age, while definitive repair of the cleft palate is typically performed between 6 and 12 months of age, as outlined in the provided reference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 months: This is the general timeframe for repairing the soft palate but is not the earliest repair. For cleft lip, the first repair usually happens earlier, at around 3 months.

 

Option C. 12 months: This is more appropriate for the repair of the hard palate and definitive palate repair, not the initial cleft lip repair.

 

Option D. 2 years: This timing is not typically relevant for the first repair of cleft lip or palate and is much later than the standard recommendations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first repair of cleft lip is typically done at around 3 months of age, following the Millard's Rule of 10, to optimize surgical outcomes and ensure the infant is prepared for the procedure.

choices.text: It should not be given with erythropoietin
It is given by intravenous route
It is more immunogenic than iron dextran
A single bolus dose is enough for treatment of iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding iron isomaltoside? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is given by intravenous route

 

Explanation:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an intravenous iron preparation that can be given via IV route over approximately 30 minutes. It is characterized by having a very low risk of allergic reactions compared to other IV iron preparations. The drug can be administered in high doses, typically requiring 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with erythropoietin: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside can be safely given with erythropoietin. It's iron ferromoxitol that should be avoided with erythropoietin.

 

Option C. It is more immunogenic than iron dextran: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside has very low immunogenicity and is less immunogenic than iron dextran.

 

Option D. A single bolus dose is enough for treatment: Incorrect. Usually 2-3 doses are required for complete treatment, though occasionally one dose might be sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an IV iron preparation characterized by low immunogenicity, compatibility with erythropoietin, and typically requires 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

 

Injectable Iron

  • Preparations of injectable iron are:
    • Iron Dextran-Can be given IV as well as IM
    • Iron Sorbital citrate (Used im olnly)
  • Intramuscular iron is given by Z-tract technique to avoid pigmentation

 

Indication of injectable iron:

  • Oral iron cannot be given e.g.
    • Malabsorption
    • Not tolerated (due to GI symptoms)
  • Given with erythropoietin
    • Erythropoietin will stinulate RBC formation and will unmask any iron deficiency 
  • Dose of injectable iron = 4.3 x Hb deficit (g/dl) x body weight (kg)
    • This formula includes the iron required for replenishment of stores also.

questions.text: Which one of these is not used for body fat evaluation? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breslow index 

 

  • The Breslow index is a measurement used specifically in dermatology to determine the depth of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. 
  • It measures the thickness of the tumor and is critical for staging the cancer and determining treatment and prognosis. Therefore, it is not related to the assessment of body fat or overall body composition.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Quetelet's index:  This is another name for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is widely used to estimate body fat based on an individual's weight and height. It provides a useful general indicator of health risks associated with body fat levels.
 

Option B. Total body potassium: This measure is used to estimate body cell mass and, indirectly, muscle mass, since potassium is primarily found in muscle tissue. Total body potassium can be an indicator of body composition, including body fat.
 

Option C. Total body water: This is used to assess hydration status and body composition. The amount of water in the body can be indicative of muscle mass (which holds a high water content) compared to fat (which holds less), thus providing insights into body fat levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Breslow index assesses the depth of melanoma skin cancer. It is crucial to recognize that this index serves a specific purpose in clinical dermatology and oncology, unrelated to nutritional or fitness assessments.

 

Obesity indices are –

 

  • Broca’s Index: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) – 100
  • Quetelet’s Index (Body Mass Index /BMI): BMI = Weight (kg) / Height (m)2
  • Corpulence Index (CI) = Actual weight/Desirable weight
  • Ponderal Index (PI)

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mannitol

 

The patient is experiencing Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), a complication that can occur during or after hemodialysis, especially in patients with initially very high urea levels undergoing dialysis for the first time. DDS is caused by a rapid decrease in urea levels in the blood, leading to a sudden change in osmolarity, which causes water to move into the cells, resulting in cerebral edema and neurological symptoms such as drowsiness and seizures.

 

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS): This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms due to cerebral edema caused by rapid changes in blood urea levels during dialysis.
  • Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic is used to treat cerebral edema by reducing intracranial pressure and drawing fluid out of the brain cells, thus decreasing cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bumetanide: This loop diuretic is used for fluid overload but not specifically indicated for treating cerebral edema in DDS.

 

Option B. Ethacrynic acid: Another loop diuretic, similar to bumetanide, and not used for DDS.

 

Option C. Nesiritide: A recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide used in acute heart failure, not for treating DDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment for Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), which can occur during or after dialysis, involves reducing cerebral edema. The first-line treatment is mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

questions.text: Which nerve seems to be damaged in the given picture? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

RADIAL NERVE

 

  • It is usually injured in fractures of shaft humerus, injection palsy, Saturday night palsy and Crutch palsy.
  • There is sensory loss in area supplied posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost (i.e. wrist, thumb and finger drops).

 

Types of Radial Nerve Lesion

 

  1. Very high (i.e. above spiral groove): there is Total palsy, i.e. Elbow, wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost. There is loss of sensation over dorsum of 1st web space.
  2. High (i.e. between spiral groove and lateral epicondyle): Elbow extension is spared. Brachioradialis is involved. Wrist, thumb, finger extension and sensation over dorsum of 1st web space are lost.
  3. Low (i.e. the elbow): Elbow and wrist extension are spared. Thumb, finger extension and sensation over dorsum of 1st web space are lost.
  4. Posterior interosseous nerve palsy (no Sensory deficit): Elbow and wrist joint extension, and sensations are spared. There is loss of MCP joint extension, i.e. thumb and finger drop.

 

 

  • The loss of synergic action between wrist flexors and extensors causes excessive and unwanted wrist flexion. This can be observed in a simple gripping task or asking the individual to make a fist. Both tasks will be difficult to complete as movement will be ineffective.
  • The hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve. In ulnar nerve injury, there is weakness of ulnar deviation & wrist flexion, atrophy of hypothenar eminence, weakness of palmar interossei (positive card test), weakness of finger adduction (Wartenberg’s sign), paralysis of adductor pollicis (positive froment’s sign), weak abduction of middle finger due to weak dorsal interossei (positive igawa’s test). The characteristic deformity seen is Ulnar claw hand i.e., hyperextension of MCP joint & flexion of IP joint.

 

 

 

 

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. The axillary nerve is injured in the fracture of surgical neck of humerus, anterior & inferior shoulder dislocation, & intramuscular injections. This causes deltoid muscle palsy; loss of rounded shoulder contour, giving shoulder a flattened appearance & producing a hollow inferior to acromion. 15-90⁰ of shoulder abduction becomes weak, and there is teres minor palsy also.

 

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve supplies coracobrachialis, the biceps brachii and the brachialis, and is continued into the forearm as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm. In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm. It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial nerve injury is associated with wrist drop i.e., loss of wrist, thumb and fingers of the affected hand, as shown in the image in the question.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.

 

Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PaO2/FiO2 ratio 200-300 mm/Hg

 

Option A:

 

The Berlin definition of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) classifies the severity based on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio assessed under specific conditions of oxygenation support. According to this definition, a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 200-300 mmHg characterizes mild ARDS, not moderate ARDS. Moderate ARDS is defined by a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 100-200 mm/Hg when assessed with at least 5 cm of water Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP).

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Bilateral interstitial infiltrates: This is correct and consistent with all classifications of ARDS, which require bilateral opacities on imaging, either from chest radiographs or CT, indicative of pulmonary edema not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload.

 

Option C. Symptom onset within a week: True for the Berlin definition, which stipulates that ARDS must occur within 7 days of a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms.

 

Option D. No cardiac failure on echocardiography: Also true according to the Berlin definition, as the pulmonary edema should not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload, thus necessitating the exclusion of cardiac failure through echocardiography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2012 Berlin Definition:

 

  1. Onset within 7 days after a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms
  2. B/L opacities (Alveolar/Interstitial that are "consistent with pulmonary edema" on chest radiographs or chest CT)
  3. Minimum PEEP setting or CPAP, 5 cm of water.

 

PaO2: FiO2 assessed on invasive mechanical ventilation (CPAP criterion used for the diagnosis of mild ARDS).

 

Categorization of ARDS severity (on the basis of FiO2):

 

  1. Mild: 200-300
  2. Moderate: 100-200
  3. Severe: <100

 

In resource limited settings Kigali Modifications was proposed (2016):

 

  1. Bilateral opacities could be documented by either ultrasonography or chest radiograph.
  2. Oxygenation criteria: pulse oximetry oxygen saturation (SpO2)/FiO2 ratio ≤ 315 without the requirement for PEEP.

 

Reference - Harrison/Respiratory Failure/Chap 301

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass in her right breast that she first noticed about 3 months ago. On physical examination, the mass is well-circumscribed, lobulated, and larger than 5 cm in diameter. A history of a similar lesion occurred 2 years back also. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histological examination reveals the image as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phyllodes tumor

 

Phyllodes tumor is a rare breast tumor that typically presents in middle-aged women (fourth to fifth decade). It is characterized by rapid growth, a lobulated appearance, and often exceeds 5 cm in diameter.

 

Phyllodes tumors can be distinguished from fibroadenomas by their stromal overgrowth and the presence of characteristic leaf-like projections seen in histological examinations. The image shows a stromal tumor with these classical leaf-like projections, confirming the diagnosis of Phyllodes tumor.

 

Phyllodes tumors can recur and have a low risk of becoming malignant, setting them apart from benign fibroadenomas and malignant carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: This is the most common type of breast cancer, characterized by a solid mass with irregular borders. It typically presents with more aggressive features, such as lymphovascular invasion, which are absent in this case. The histology does not show the leaf-like stromal projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option C. Fibroadenoma: A common benign breast tumor seen mostly in younger women, characterized by a well-circumscribed, mobile mass. Histologically, it shows a mix of glandular and stromal elements but lacks the prominent stromal overgrowth and leaf-like projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option D. Ductal papilloma: This benign tumor involves the breast ducts and often presents with nipple discharge rather than a large, rapidly growing mass. The histological appearance is distinct from that of Phyllodes tumors, lacking the stromal and leaf-like characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phyllodes tumors are rapidly growing, lobulated breast masses with characteristic leaf-like stromal projections on histology, commonly seen in middle-aged women, and may recur.

questions.text: Identify: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Venous ulcer

 

The correct answer is Venous ulcer. Venous ulcers, also known as ulcers of varicose veins, typically occur on the medial aspect of the lower leg, just above the medial malleolus. They are often found in the "gaiter" area and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. The ulcers are usually shallow with irregular borders, and the surrounding skin may show signs of venous stasis, such as hyperpigmentation and edema. The presence of varicose veins and the ulcer's location on the medial side strongly indicate a venous origin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischemic ulcer: Ischemic ulcers are generally located on the tips of toes, pressure points, or other areas that experience reduced blood flow. They have well-defined borders and a punched-out appearance. The location and presentation in this case do not match ischemic ulcers.

 

Option C. Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are usually associated with neuropathy, often seen in diabetic patients. They occur on pressure points such as the plantar surface of the foot and are characterized by a loss of protective sensation. The location above the medial malleolus does not fit with trophic ulcers.

 

Option D.  Infectious ulcer: Infectious ulcers can occur anywhere on the body and are characterized by overt signs of infection like pus, redness, and warmth. While infection can complicate venous ulcers, the primary cause in this case is venous insufficiency, not infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers are typically found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. Recognizing their characteristic location and appearance is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.text: A patient presented with retro-orbital pain and rash since the 5 days. Most appropriate test to be done now is:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody detection by ELISA

 

When diagnosing dengue fever, the timing of the test is crucial. Dengue virus infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus, its RNA, or its antigens, as well as by detecting antibodies against the virus.

 

NS1 Ag ELISA (Option A) and Dengue RNA by PCR (Option B) are methods used to detect the presence of the dengue virus or its antigens in the early stages of the infection, typically within the first 1-5 days of symptom onset. This is because the viral load and antigen levels are highest during this period.

 

Antibody detection by ELISA (Option C) becomes more appropriate after the initial phase of infection, typically after 5-7 days. At this point, the patient's immune system has started producing antibodies (IgM and IgG) against the virus, which can be detected using ELISA.

 

Viral culture (Option D), while definitive, is not typically used in routine clinical practice due to its complexity, cost, and time requirements.

 

Since the patient has been symptomatic for 5 days, it is likely that antibodies have begun to be produced. Therefore, the most appropriate test at this stage is the detection of antibodies by ELISA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS1 Ag ELISA: This test is most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection when the NS1 antigen is present in the blood. After this period, its sensitivity decreases.

 

Option B. Dengue RNA by PCR: This test is also most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection for detecting the viral RNA. After this period, the viral load decreases, making the test less effective.

 

Option D. Viral culture: This method is not commonly used in routine practice due to its complexity and time-consuming nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms for more than 5 days, the most appropriate diagnostic test is antibody detection by ELISA, as antibodies are typically present after 5-7 days of infection.
